body:
I'm not sure what you mean by "second class citizen in fallback mode". All you need to do is have `export const ssr = false` at the root of your project, and you have a good ol' SPA.
To preconfigure the adapter seems limiting because `adapter-static` isn't suitable for all deployment targets - or rather, it's way easier to for example use `adapter-vercel` to deploy your SPA to Vercel. Furthermore, there's a step-by-step section in `adapter-static` that tells you what to do in order to create an SPA with it.

That said, it sounds like you already know this, so I'm curious what makes you think that SPA's are not a first class citizen.

https://github.com/sveltejs/kit/issues/754

https://kit.svelte.dev/docs/adapter-static#spa-mode

Google "svelte SPA mode" leads to quite some links, I would claim it's a popular demand, yes I can tweak Sveltekit to get a kind-of SPA mode, but it's not a first-class citizen to me. For SSR I got it out of box, for CSR(i.e. SPA mode) I need jump a few hoops and there is not even a client-side route package from the kit(I need add that myself), also, why CSR|SPA needs a different fallback home page instead of just index.html.

SPA use cases for many have nothing to do with hosting companies(e.g. Vercel), for me it's an internal project to control embedded devices, and probably a frontend for Tauri|Wails, no SEO or SSR needed at all.

What do you mean by a 'client-side route package'?

The fallback page is needed because that's how SPAs work. You need to have an HTML file that is served for all requests, regardless of path. You can call the fallback page `index.html` if that's what works for whatever webserver you're using.

> I need jump a few hoops

I count one â€” `export const ssr = false`. Two if you want to use `adapter-static` (which isn't necessarily the case, since you might have API routes etc) in which case you need to configure a fallback. I'm honestly not sure how much easier we could make it?

It would be really nice that `npm create svelte@latest` offers an option called SPA, that has the `ssr=off` set and fallback to index.html and set prerender to [ ] etc, then remove all those files that are only for SSR under src/routes/), so I can have a clean SPA boilerplate out of the box. This will be quite useful for those of us who do not do SSR and SEO(there are quite some users for that), and also make sveltekit a true framework that offers SPA and SSR out of the box. It's like Vue + Nuxt into one to me. Thanks!
I think there are many from vue(not Nuxt) to svelte are expecting a framework for pure SPA as they had in vue.

Ah, the "SvelteKit demo app" is not a good choice if you want a SPA. Maybe we should rename that choice to "SvelteKit SSR demo app" to make it clearer that "Skeleton project" is a better one to start with if you want a SPA

The trouble with this approach is that the definition of 'SPA' is very fuzzy. Many people these days use it to mean something like the SvelteKit default (i.e. server-rendered pages with client-side routing), for example. For some people it implies a single `index.html` shell (your definition would require adapter-static to be installed and configured to use a fallback page, though the name of the fallback page will differ from one webserver to another), but for others it purely describes the rendering and routing approach, and doesn't preclude dynamically rendered API routes (which means you _can't_ use adapter-static).

So there's no single definition that would make sense for inclusion in the `create-svelte` template list (and we don't want the list to balloon with lots of increasingly complex options).

On top of that, while there _are_ valid reasons to build something without SSR, it's a bad default for the majority of projects, so we want there to be a _little_ bit of friction.

We could possibly add a page to the docs explaining all of the above, but I don't see us changing anything in the framework itself.

> Ah, the "SvelteKit demo app" is not a good choice if you want a SPA. Maybe we should rename that choice to "SvelteKit SSR demo app" to make it clearer that "Skeleton project" is a better one to start with if you want a SPA

Absolutely esp for new comers, I did not expect defaut demo option is SSR indeed, quite the opposite I expected it is a SPA which is the default for similar projects like vue and react.
SvelteKit isn't analogous to Vue and React though, it's analogous to Nuxt and Next

Which is not clear on the home page, it should have a bold font saying something like SSR-framework for Svelte(or Nuxt|Next for Svelte) so at least for those who are not interested in SSR be aware.

I guess I will need use svelte + vite instead of sveltekit for my SPA(the original SPA idea that is: CSR only) projects.

To be clear you can absolutely create such SPAs with SvelteKit, all you need is what's described in the SPA section of adapter-static which you intended to use. The file based routing is independent of the rendering mode.

I agree with Rich that we don't need to change something inside Kit itself, and that it's more about better documentation of the different rendering modes, how you use them, and what that means for adapters. "Page options" is a good starting point but needs more in-depth explanations and maybe also more prominently linked from other places.

I've recently started using kit and wanted to turn it into SPA ONLY mode and I've also thought the SSR was first class citizen in kit but there is no first class citizen in sveltekit, it's just flexible - all levers are turned on by default. That being said it's in my opinion a fault of flexible framework to not explicitly indicate what rendering modes it is globally using without digging into documentation defaults because it just markets itself as "flexible".
Why not at least ship `+layout.js` with default options (+ maybe some comments/link to docs for every mode) inside skeleton project? I think it would help to quickly test out ssr/csr/prerender modes for people who don't want to jump right into docs from the beginning.

One extra thing that confused me was that sveltekit does not indicate/still builds ssr bundle when SSR is disabled globally during build - it still builds and shows "building SSR bundle for production" even though generated files from this step are not even used with static adapter.

It is a SSR-first framework.

Yes you can make it SPA but it's not really that clean to me.

I created a SPA-only mode for myself in the end: https://github.com/laoshaw/sveltespa

body:
> it still builds and shows "building SSR bundle for production" even though generated files from this step are not even used with static adapter

They _are_ used â€” they're used during prerendering

> > it still builds and shows "building SSR bundle for production" even though generated files from this step are not even used with static adapter
> 
> They _are_ used â€” they're used during prerendering

True... I missed that, should've noted CSR only (`ssr = false prerender = false`) instead of SSR still does it with this combination but it seems without server directory it breaks `preview` too so it wouldn't be trivial to disable it I guess?

Even if SSR is disabled, you still need a server (whether to respond to requests dynamically or for prerendering) - something has to serve up the empty app shell. It's true that you could theoretically get away without building all the component code in SSR mode, but we're talking about extra complexity for fairly minimal gains

I think one of the things that may help people using hoping to make a single-page CSR app for static sites or offline applications may be the addition of a dedicated template on the svelte `npm create` template list. As a newcomer to Svelte after SvelteKit came on the scene, I was able to figure this out without too many issues, but it did require some digging into what adapter settings were needed to do so. Svelte's historical success with single-page, rich, interactive experiences for data visualization were what originally attracted me to it. In this light, I can see why other people in similar situations after SvelteKit may feel lost without having a dedicated CSR starter template to cut their teeth on.

You shouldn't be disabling SSR unless you have a good reason for it. If we offer a template, people will create CSR-only SPAs because that's what they're used to, or because there's a mistaken perception that it's somehow 'easier', and users will suffer a worse experience as a result.
That is a good point. My use case is indeed pretty niche, so the expectation of having to do a bit more setup than the common/best practice case is not unreasonable.

> You shouldn't be disabling SSR unless you have a good reason for it. If we offer a template, people will create CSR-only SPAs because that's what they're used to, or because there's a mistaken perception that it's somehow 'easier', and users will suffer a worse experience as a result.

My backend has no nodejs at all, why should SSR be turned on? there are many REST-like backends that do not run nodejs, I'm not sure if SSR works when no node is used, I have yet to know more about SSR.
For me my use case is actually an embedded board running C but provides REST for SPA, I see no point I need anything SSR at all.

I have same problem, I've been work with C# for long time, I don't have any reason to run both ASP.Net & nodejs server in same project. There is no official dot.net core adopter here. I had to write my own  adaptor https://github.com/Kiho/svelte-adapter-aspcore
But I can't find any reason to use svelte kit SSR over SPA with lots more of complexity.

SPA-without-SSR has lots of use cases, in fact it is why Angluar|React|Vue|Svelte exist at the beginning.  Sveltekit is itself really a SSR first kit, I think it's more clear to put some statement such as "Sveltekit is a SSR first kit that works the best with nodejs backend or you need provide an adaptor" on the start of the document.

That's not true though, you can use it for SPA's just as well. It requires a little change to the default setup, that's all.
I'm split on how to proceed here. I agree with Rich that people reach for SPA's more often than they should. I disagree that SSR is just as easy - it's not. You need to think about two environments, about global state and not leaking it etc. That's a lot to ask from a newcomer or someone used to this style, especially if there's no need for them to change (for example of they are building internal business apps).
I think we need to do _something_ here. If our goal is to be SvelteKit be the tool you reach for for all apps and sizes, no matter if you're a beginner or not, the barrier for entry needs to be lower

Would it be enough to add a warning to this page: https://kit.svelte.dev/docs/creating-a-project

Something like this:

> By default, SvelteKit scaffolds a project with server side rendering that comes with many benefits for web-based sites including [progressive enhancement](https://kit.svelte.dev/docs/form-actions#progressive-enhancement). It's possible to opt out of SSR on a per-route basis, though if you wish to build a completely static site, or a single page application for a good reason such as situations that don't require SEO, native applications, or embedded software; then look into using [adapter-static](https://kit.svelte.dev/docs/adapter-static) with SvelteKit.

Though SSR is generally encouraged, and SPAs are lightly discouraged to appeal to the majority of users authoring websites, adapter-static is an official solution that can be represented a bit earlier in the docs.

> Would it be enough to add a warning to this page: https://kit.svelte.dev/docs/creating-a-project
> 
> Something like this:
> 
> > By default, SvelteKit scaffolds a project with server side rendering that comes with many benefits for web-based sites including [progressive enhancement](https://kit.svelte.dev/docs/form-actions#progressive-enhancement). It's possible to opt out of SSR on a per-route basis, though if you wish to build a completely static site, or a single page application for a good reason such as situations that don't require SEO, native applications, or embedded software; then look into using [adapter-static](https://kit.svelte.dev/docs/adapter-static) with SvelteKit.
> 
> Though SSR is generally encouraged, and SPAs are lightly discouraged to appeal to the majority of users authoring websites, adapter-static is an official solution that can be represented a bit earlier in the docs.

This is better for sure, and works for certain use cases.

For CSR-only SPA applications, I feel Sveltekit is just not the right fit as there is no need to have **anything** in the boilerplate for SSR at all: neither in the code nor in the document. 

For example Vuejs has a SPA boilerplate(the original vuejs, e.g. pnpm create vue@latest) and if you need Nuxt, do `npm init nuxt-app`,  in Svelte's case, I would expect something like: `npm create svelte` for CSR-only SPA and if I need SSR(and its adapters) I do `npm create sveltekit` logically. I would never expect the default `svelte` naming in `npm create svelte` now is actually for a SSR-oriented boilerplate.

I will maintain my own CSR SPA svelte boilerplate with client-side routing for now, but it's a bit disappointing that Svelte does not have a CSR-SPA boilerplate as the **default** like what Vue and React have been providing all the time. Yes I read all the sveltekit docs and I know the adapters and static-adapters, but it's not what CSR-SPA really wants.

If you want a SPA, SvelteKit is still what you want to use because you will need a router, which SvelteKit provides. It's much easier to setup a SvelteKit project and turn on SPA mode than it is to try to setup a router on your own which will not be nearly as well maintained or documented.

> there's a mistaken perception that it's somehow 'easier'

It sounds like one of the main drivers of that is that a lot of people have accounts with legacy hosting providers and can easily deploy a SPA (i.e. static files) there whereas to deploy an SSR-based solution they sometimes need to create a new account at a serverless provider or obtain a VPS to run their own Node instance. It sounds like some CPanels will let you run Node and some won't and when you can it's not always obvious how to set it up (we should probably document it). If you're starting from scratch, the serverless option is probably the easiest, but if you have an account at a legacy hosting provider and don't want to move from it for whatever reason then I can see people reaching for a SPA even if it's not better for users because it might be the easier choice from a deployment perspective.

A few examples:
- https://www.reddit.com/r/sveltejs/comments/ookqde/how_do_i_deploy_my_sveltekit_app/
- https://stackoverflow.com/questions/71278902/can-i-deploy-a-svelte-kit-app-on-php-hosting-without-nodejs
- https://stackoverflow.com/questions/72820259/sveltekit-nodejs-build-not-running-in-cpanel-on-shared-hosting
